yo juego Overwatch 2, siempre he sido tanque y siempre discuto con mis compañeros que son medicos, osea los que curan.
pues mis compañeros, los que se supone tienen que curar hacen otras cosas, no entienden que la unica clase que importa es el tanque, los demas no importan, porque con los tanques se ganan las partidas.
los que somos buenos tenemos que soportar que en una partida nos toque un equipo de novatos que no cumplen los objetivos, y que por culpa de ellos terminamos perdiendo la partida; entonces no es justo, que a pesar que uno se esfuerza tanto en una partida, terminemos perdiendo por culpa del equipo, el cual no cumplio los objetivos y por eso terminamos enojados y estresados.
yo solo juego con jugadores de PlayStation 4 o PlayStation 5 si he jugado con jugadores de Xbox, PC o Nintendo Switch, pero, la mayoria de las veces que juego con personas que son de esas plataformas, pues a esas personas se les va la conexion por lo que prefiero jugar con usuarios que sean de PlayStation 4 o PlayStation 5; asi que si quieren jugar conmigo pasenme su ID.

Blizzard bad, game good

Fast alle negativen Rezensionen hier, sind purer Hass auf Blizzard wegen ihrer Monetarisierungsstrategie. Man kann das auch absolut verstehen, Blizzard ist zu einem Synonym für Gier geworden. Diablo Immortal und Diablo 4 sind eine Katastrophe! 
Das hat aber nichts mit Overwatch zu tun und diese Rezensionen werden Overwatch nicht gerecht. Man muss die Storykampagne nicht spielen, das hat absolut keinen Einfluss auf das eigentliche Multiplayer-Overwatch wie wir es schon seit vielen Jahren lieb gewonnen haben. Also bitte ignoriert die Wut und Cancel-Culture vieler Rezensenten, denn das Spiel ist einfach genial. Kein anderes MMO-FPS hat es geschafft mich so viele Jahre zu fesseln und kein anderes Spiel schafft es, mich so die Zeit vergessen zu lassen. Die Runden sind fordernd, extrem spannend und jede Runde ist anders. Der Battlepass motiviert, auch wenn man nicht zahlen möchte. Aber es ist ein "Game as a service", also kann man auch ab und zu etwas zurückgeben für die vielen geilen Stunden die man in dem Spiel verbringt, oder? Blizzard investiert viel Zeit in neue Skins, Karten, das Balancing, neue Helden, eSport, etc. Ich bin absolut kein Fan von F2P, durch diesen Trend sind auch diese ganzen negativen Kommentare hier entstanden. Das wichtigste bei Overwatch2 ist aber, kein P2W und die Preise für den Battle Pass gehen in Ordnung.
Der Release auf Steam ist einfach genial, mit dem Blizzard Account anmelden, fertig. Alle Einstellungen (inkl. Grafik), die Progression inkl. detaillierter Statistik seit dem Release von Overwatch 1, alles ist da, top!
Ja, für Wiedereinsteiger die von Overwatch 1 kommen, ist es erstmal sehr gewöhnungsbedürftig mit 5 Helden und nur einem Tank. Doch schon nach kurzer Zeit merkt man, dass diese Aenderungen absolut Sinn machen. Das Spiel ist dadurch noch actionreicher und abwechselnder geworden, diese Neuerungen sind also absolut gelungen!

没想到到了2023年终于有一个我能理直气壮写测评的游戏了(●ˇ∀ˇ●)
恭喜守望先锋上架steam！
让我想想，该从哪里说起？
从《双龙》？
从“年度最佳游戏”？
从上海龙42连败到冠军？
从济南屁王？
从PVE？
算了，
让我来说一说，阿育陀耶的落日。
阿育陀耶的正中间有一个莲花池，从左边沿着楼梯上去，半透明的白色纱帘飞舞，纱帘后是遥远的群山，和隐匿于群山之后，只留下光芒的太阳。
有时候我会在阿育陀耶的悬崖边坐一晚上，看着夕阳。
或许这不是落日，而是日出？不管如何我是武断地认为这是落日了。
小王子说他最难过的时候看了43次落日。
我的落日呢？
它永远挂在天上，却也永远看不见形状，这样永恒的落日，又是否代表了永恒的泪水呢？
我从暮色四合等到晨曦初露，也没有等到我想要的答案。

2016年的暑假，闷热昏暗的客厅，我悄悄地偷出我爸的笔记本下载了OW，进了游戏后，人物模型模糊的好像我400度的眼镜没带一样，但我居然玩下去了。
在阿努比斯神殿B点正中的三个小门，我拿着Dva和堡垒站在一起，试图将B点大门的敌人打死。
在花村的A点，我拿着小美，狂按左键，试图冻住在钟旁跟我二人转的对手。
我一开始是不屑于玩辅助的，初三的时候总觉得自己会是世界第一DPS，结果错过了天使群拉==
2019年，大家从高中毕业，各奔东西。我终于有了一些可以支配的资金，毫不犹豫地买了OW豪华版，并且开始四处寻找队友。嘿，还真给我找到了。自此我们的玩具车成立。同年OW2的cg让我对这个游戏充满了希望。
2020年，我开始看pva的直播，经常看到半夜，翻来覆去地看云水遥遥写的短篇，为了狙击pva苦练技术但最终也只上了个钻石。
2021年凌晨，我们车队所有人都换了金刀，在游戏里六个金刀源氏一起合影过元旦。
2022年10月2日，天使陪着我在阿育陀耶看着落日，迎来了OW1的谢幕。
2023年1月24日，国服的一切终止在斗兽场的大白旁。

现在已经是2023年8月11日了，是没有PVE的OW2，是全面溃烂的济南屁王，是没有金刀的源氏，是上不去的排位分，没有等级边框的外服，梦一样消散的国服。我也不再在阿育陀耶看落日。

7年，很遥远吗？
7年，是86个月，是2634天，是63240个小时。
7年，却也只是419个字符。
7年过去了，守望先锋的世界一片混乱，我的世界也没有变得更好。
不论如何我确实无法割舍与守望先锋之间的感情了，它参与了我这几年的每一个日夜，一个逐渐变成无聊的大人的人和一个逐渐落寞的游戏，是非常契合的。
守望先锋还是我最喜欢的游戏，但我确实也不再如以前那样喜欢守望先锋。
有时候我打开它，却停留在主页发呆。
什么时候能看到阿育陀耶的日出呢？
会者定离，
一期一祈。

I have played this game on and off since 2016. The recent management of PVE, their bad office culture that allegedly led to a female staff member sadly ending her own life are all parts off my increasing amount of hatred for this game and their management. 

Then the game came out I loved it and played it quiet alot, but in it's state and frankly the state it has been in since OW2 was announced is not a game I can nor will ever recommend to anyone. What I presume to be the upper-management has transformed a once great game into a machine made to suck all your money and enjoyment of the game out of you. From Battle Passes to locking heroes away behind a pay wall and making the long anticipated PvE mode behind a paywall just to earn a bit of money short term. Some people might deny this but the fact that this game has even moved to Steam is proof of how badly it has been treated by thous making decisions.

I feel bad for the truly passionate and dedicated talents that have worked under the aforementioned office culture and terrible management of what seems to have started out as a passion project from a large and talented team from Blizzard then it was at it's best.
Ahhh yes, and now its time for a proper review.

This game is a shell of the game it used to be. 

The game has gone downhill ever since Jeff Kaplan left. The game has lost its sense of direction and inspiration. Balance is questionable and pretty obvious that they don't really know how to balance many of the characters. 

Context:
I am a Masters ranked Support Main (previous Tank Main) with ~500 hours across Overwatch 1 and Overwatch 2 in Blizzard's Battle.net client.

Gameplay: 
They removed a core game mode from the original game, 2CP (2 control points), and added an arguably worst gamemode called Push. The Push game mode does a poor job at fostering teamplay, as it becomes a series of chip damage until one player from either side inevitably gets one-shot and picked off, making it a 4 versus 5. This is not as much of a problem in OW1 (Overwatch 1) as there were teams of 6, so picking someone off is not as important, being a 5 v 6 instead. 2CP was a lot more team oriented by giving the defense 2 common points to group around. This naturally prevented the defending team from slowly trickling out and getting picked off one by one, waiting for everyone to group up, an eternity that never comes. Thus, the attacking team has to group and coordinate an attack on the defending team. 

The problem with Push in this regard is the team that was wiped has a shorter spawn than the team that won the team fight. This is because the winning team pushes the robot closer to the enemy spawn, and thus the team that lost has a chance to group against the now weakened winning team as their dead members are trickling in from their spawns. This back and forth and how long the map is, plus how incredulously slow the Push robot is, makes the gamemode take an eternity and incredibly boring to play. In addition, the game tries to balance the game modes equally for the two gamemodes in the game. The biggest problem is that they only had three maps for the Push gamemode, making it not only slow and boring to play, but also feel incredibly repetitive getting the same maps after map. 

Balance: 
As I mentioned earlier, they decreased the amount of players on each team. This comes with a lot of balancing issues. As explained earlier, this causes picking off players to be incredibly valuable, as each death has very significant impact on the team. Heroes with high one-shot potential such as Hanzo and Widowmaker (they even added another one (Sojourn) for some reason??) become too useful. That combined with the fact that there is only one tank to protect the backline from them makes the game fundamentally broken without essentially removing these characters (or nerfing them into the ground which they have basically done). With two tanks, one tank could protect their backline while the other could put pressure on the snipers. In OW2 (Overwatch 2), unless the backline is also diving with the tank, they get left to dry with no shield (or meat shield) to protect them as they just try and survive against the opposing tank and damage dealers running at them. 

Another problem arose with the removal of the second tank. The tanks now have to be able to survive as if they had two tanks, so the solution they found was to just give them a butt-load of health. However, having a ton of health isn't enough to make space for the team. They are now essentially a walking battery to charge the enemy ultimates. Lacking purpose and threat, their solution now was to give them loads of damage. This essentially turns the role into a better, stronger dps (damage dealer) role. While this fixes the problem with no one wanting to play tank in the orginal game, they are now way too strong in the current game. 

As mentioned earlier, with fewer obstacles in the way between the enemy team and the backline, it makes it incredibly hard for supports to survive in OW2. With supports having the lowest (average) damage in the game and few tools to defend themselves, they become even easier targets in this game. This is not to mention they have the least agency and the least impact in the game, being mainly a reactive role rather than a proactive role. This obviously made the support role the least desired role. At least as a support main, the queue times are short ᕕ( ᐛ )ᕗ.

Speaking of queues, the matchmaking is incredibly frustrating. Being a Master player and getting put in the same ranked lobbies as silver and gold players is ridiculous. This is already a huge problem in itself as clearly someone who has 100s to 1000s of hours shouldn't be put in the same games as someone with 10 hours in the game. Assuming the teams are balanced, for example having maybe 1 lower ranked player on each side (which doesn't even always happen), the bigger issue arises when the lowest ranked player is the tank. With how strong the tank role is, having a weaker tank mostly likely means a loss. With their inexperience in team fighting and positioning, they end up either way too far forward being in the middle of the enemy team, or off to the side chasing a Genji for far too long as the rest of team is getting run down. This isn't the tanks' fault, but they matchmaking shouldn't allow for these situations (at least as frequently).

PvE Monetization:
All of this and not to mention the entire reason they made OW2 was to make a PvE (Player versus Environment) mode that they later said they couldn't do, and are now saying that they are going to do it... if you give them more money. I probably don't have to say how incredibly stupid that sounds, not to mention that I already paid full price for the original game, but because they made the game free to play, they are going to be charging me for it.

Conclusion:
With the removal of an essential role and lack of critical balancing that should come with the removal of the role and removal of an essential game mode with a replacement with a vastly inferior gamemode, the game feels incredibly shallow compared to what the game was originally. That combined with their questionable business decisions makes it obvious that they lack of direction and are clearly not focused on the integrity of the game, but rather to milk anyone and everyone out of their money.

I used to love Overwatch in the hundreds of hours I've played, and I still have lots of fun with it sometimes.

However, even with all the many [i]many[/i] problems the game now has, there is one single thing that keeps me from recommending the game to anyone: new heroes are deep in the battlepass, but you get them instantly if you pay.

In a game all about team composition and counter picks, the absolute worst thing they could do was monetize heroes, but they did it anyways. Despite all the other many issues with the game, this single thing is the most damning, to me.
100% not worth it, don't play it, the company is as greedy and lazy as it gets also it's a cheap Paladins and TF2 Clone GG
